Articles.Content: So. Is this "so crazy it might just work" or is it just crazy?
It doesn't look THAT crazy, but it also probably won't work

Only one way to find out!

That said... I'm looking at those two small side boosters, and I'm wondering about their exhaust.  If those boosters fire with everything else, could their exhaust overheat the core stage?  If so, you could be looking at an explosive ending to your mission.

That just looks like some Kerbal engineering to me! and so long as you've got something to counteract the offset weight and drag of the wheels (either a carefully placed counter weight or just an overpowered, over SAS'd LV), it could work.

I don't see why this wouldn't work... It's hard to guess if you will have enough SAS and/or Gimbal to compensate the drag but that's another question.

For very draggy rocket, the trick is to Launch STRAIGHT UP until 25km-35km (depending how much your SAS-Gimbal can overtake the drag). The idea is that once you get to 35km, there isn't much air left to make you spin... THEN you make your (quite abrupt) gravity turn.

I launch silly stuff like that (and way worst) all the time. You just have to use the less-than-efficient launch profile I mention and pack up a bit more delta-V to compensate. I plan for ~4500m/s and that's usually enough to make orbit with a little margin even with horribly draggy stuff.

20 minutes ago, Perotis said:

So. Is this "so crazy it might just work" or is it just crazy?

In my expert opinion of an expert of explosions, yes.
It flew surprisingly well.  I'm just trying to see if I can stick the mun landing
Landing attempt #2 was %50 successful.  45 m/s was too much for the tires though.
Theyre repairable with right click menu if in sandbox by an engineer or suitably qualified one in career  she did well to survive
